arguments.problem_statement: Currently, users receive no automatic updates when workunits they're involved in are modified. This leads to missed deadlines, delayed responses, and reduced collaboration efficiency. We need a robust notification system that alerts users via email and in-app messages for key workunit events.
arguments.success_criteria:
1. Users receive real-time notifications (email + in-app) for workunit status changes, new tasks, assignments, and due date updates.
2. Users can customize notification preferences (channels, frequency, event types).
3. System handles 10k+ daily notifications with >99.9% delivery reliability.
4. Notification latency is under 5 seconds for critical events.
5. Audit log tracks all sent notifications for compliance.
arguments.description:
Build a comprehensive notification system that keeps users informed about workunit updates in real-time while respecting their preferences and ensuring reliability.

Key components:
- Event detection for workunit changes (status, tasks, assignments)
- Preference management UI and API
- Multi-channel delivery (email, in-app, SMS optional)
- Rate limiting and batching to prevent notification spam
- Analytics dashboard for notification engagement

arguments.title: Adopt WebSockets over polling for real-time notifications
arguments.content:
We have decided to implement real-time notifications using WebSockets instead of traditional polling mechanisms. This decision was made after evaluating the following tradeoffs:

WebSocket advantages:
- Lower latency: Near real-time delivery (typically <100ms) vs polling delays (configurable but typically seconds to minutes)
- Reduced server load: Single persistent connection per user vs repeated HTTP requests
- Better bandwidth efficiency: No repeated headers and minimal overhead per message
- Improved user experience with instant updates

WebSocket challenges:
- Connection management complexity (reconnection logic, state synchronization)
- Resource usage on the server (maintaining open connections)
- Scaling considerations (requires connection-aware load balancing)
- Firewall/proxy compatibility issues in some enterprise environments

Polling alternatives considered but rejected:
- Short polling: Higher latency and more HTTP overhead
- Long polling: Better than short polling but still less efficient than WebSockets
- Server-Sent Events (SSE): One-way communication only (server to client), insufficient for our bidirectional needs

Implementation approach:
1. Establish WebSocket connection on client login/session start
2. Implement reconnection logic with exponential backoff
3. Use Redis pub/sub for scaling across multiple server instances
4. Add heartbeat mechanism to detect stale connections
5. Fallback to short polling if WebSocket connection fails after retries

This decision aligns with our success criteria of <5 second latency for critical events and provides a foundation for future interactive features.
